review: Just enjoy it for what it is The movie is fun and enjoyable. Good action and CGI. It lacks character depth and archs. / Character Development / Superman for example is the same man we meet at the start of the movie and leave at the end of the movie, nothing minor or major happens that makes him a different man: better or worse. For example: In Ironman (2008) we see Tony Stark becomes a completely new person that has new beliefs at the end of the movie. He even shuts down his own weapons department at Stark Industries. The Batman (2022) ends with Bruce finally understands he must change from a symbol of vengeance to one of hope for the people. But in Superman nothing pretty much happens to the character of Clark Kent. That goes for all characters in the movie. They all miss any character development at all. / Story and Characters / The story is very basic, one dimensional and sometimes irrelevant in the context of the movie itself which puts action and CGI fights above all. The relationship between Louis and Superman/ Clark Kent is disregard at best. Same goes for the metahumans, the Daily Planet journalists, and even the main villain (Lex Luthor) who is the only thing that will give you hope about having a good rivalry between him and Superman in the future. Nicholas Hoult (Lex Luthor) is amazing as the character but he was let down by the script. Edi Gathegi (Mr. Terrific) was good. Nathan Fillion (Guy Gardener) was okay giving the limited time he appears on the screen. Overall the secondary characters was all cast well, but the script itself didn't help the actors much. Even Skyler Gisondo did okay as (Jimmy Olsen). / Summary / If you are a general movie fan or a Marvel fan and you just want to have a good time with some laughs and smiles... this movie is for you. If you are a hardcore cinema fan who wants every movie to be as good as The Godfather or Shawshank Redemption, or as a comic book movie to be as good as Ironman and The Dark Knight and will not settle for anything less... this isn't for you. I enjoyed it for what it is. Final Score: (). 1

review: A Superman who can fly after a few falls. SPOILER Okay, after coming back from seeing Superman in theaters, I have to say for a reboot on the character, it was a neat movie, nothing too game changing or groundbreaking but something to have a good time with for any movie goer. While the actors are good at playing like the characters and the action is decent for the most part and cool score, the plot and the characterization are something to be desired or something that has been seen before in earlier iterations. For the Pros, I would have to give the action credit where it is due. They make the fights feel almost real especially between Superman, Engineer and Ultraman, the monster fights have good CGI. However, around the ending Superman fight the flaws in the CGI shows or feels too fake especially with the Raptors. The Score to me really carries the movie, especially the remastered 1978 Superman theme. I was unsure at first from the trailer, but I could say that it is something that makes you feel like you really want Superman to come and save the day. Some characters have nice moments, especially between Pa Kent and David Corenswet's Superman about choice makes you who you are. And Nicholas Hoult's Lex Luthor really does shine as this mastermind CEO who has it out for Superman. He makes you see the hatred quite well. Some characters have some comedic bits like Skyler Gisondo's Jimmy Olsen and Edi Gathegi's Mister Terrific and Krypto. For the Cons, to begin with is the beginning of the movie where it just feels like it just glosses over with exposition text about the current state of the DCU world. I have not really been a fan of new comic book movie iterations skipping over that and just expects me to accept how things are. Not saying that it shouldn't be a thing, I just feel that if you are going to have it, it should be done better. Like Matt Reeve's "The Batman", it didn't do an origin sub-plot but was able to convey the state of Gotham through visuals and score and tone. Throughout the movie, most of the time the story has extensive exposition, trying to explain their world or story how it led up to where it was without many visuals. As for Tone, while the movie's tone is supposed to be light-hearted, it has themes and plot-threads and scenes that makes it grim, it just makes it hard to feel hope at times. And even some scenes which is supposed to be dark feels ruined by some comedy bits like Trapping Krypto with him chasing Squirrels or using monkeys to make hate comments about Superman. There are certain points in times that the characters felt out of place from their comic book counterparts. Like in the interview with Superman and Lois Lane where they talk about Superman's actions, he doesn't appear apologetic and is more self-defensive, with harming enemies for the sake of protecting the innocent. Earlier, he took it personally when Jimmy calls out him losing a fight with Ultraman, it just makes him feel arrogant. For as smart as Lex Luthor was, keeping around girlfriends who are liabilities to security and secrecy of company activities is like a huge HIPPA violation. And his plans while true to his character feels like a repeat of Gene Hackman's Lex Luthor, defeating Superman, causing massive catastrophes and seeking to build his own utopia. I kind of saw that Ma and Pa Kent's characters portrayal makes them feel stereotypes of country folk making it sound like they are backward thinking in civilized society. As for the Justice Gang, I find that they kind of crowd the story which is for Superman. Without them and reworked some of the plot, there could have been more focus on character development between major characters. One thing I do not like one bit is the reveal with Superman's Kryptonian Parents being survivalists rather than hopeful parents for their son to make a better world. His Parents just wants Superman to conquer Earth among other things which would be equivalent to a Viltrumite from Invincible series or Saiyans from Dragon Ball. I know there are antagonistic Kryptonians in other iterations as well, but they at least have Superman's parents being morally decent compared to most of them. It reflects the hardships of Jerry Siegel's family that they immigrated to America for. Another thing that I noticed is that most of the story has lacked the "show don't tell" element to it. For example, the Hypno Glasses which makes Superman as Clark Kent appear different to everyone, yet we don't get examples of it from people's perspective, could even lead to comedic possibilities. I was indifferent mostly from the Robots in the Fortress of Solitude as they were out of the movie most of the time. Though they tried to make interactions between Superman, I felt wasn't enough. Overall, I felt like while there are quite a few plot threads and character traits in the movie I do not like. Though the characters were not all bad and the action and Musical score carries the weight for me. So, at best. 6

review: Feels like a little bit of a cartoon James Gunn's Superman (2025) launches the new DC Universe with a colorful, ensemble-driven approach that sets it apart from the darker tones of previous iterations. This isn't the brooding, tortured Superman of past decades-it's a more hopeful, humorous, and cosmic reimagining that clearly carries traces of Gunn's Guardians of the Galaxy style. David Corenswet steps into the role of Clark Kent / Superman with warmth and approachability. His version of the Man of Steel is sincere and likable, but at times feels less commanding both physically and emotionally compared to earlier portrayals. This Superman relies more on teamwork than sheer power, which might divide audiences who prefer a more self-reliant hero. Still, Corenswet brings an undeniable charm and sincerity to the role that fits Gunn's vision for a lighter, more humanized Superman. Nicholas Hoult's Lex Luthor, however, is the film's standout. He's sharp, unpredictable, and menacing in all the right ways. Hoult captures both the intelligence and arrogance of the character while adding a modern edge that keeps him fresh. It's easily one of the strongest interpretations of Lex Luthor to date-cunning, charismatic, and genuinely dangerous. Rachel Brosnahan delivers a capable performance as Lois Lane, showing confidence and chemistry with Corenswet, though her portrayal may not fully capture the timeless essence of the character. She brings energy and wit, but the emotional resonance between Lois and Clark feels slightly underdeveloped. Skyler Gisondo's Jimmy Olsen is an understated success. He doesn't have much screen time, but his grounded humor and genuine reactions make him feel like an essential part of the Daily Planet trio. His comedic timing works without ever feeling exaggerated. Edi Gathegi as Mr. Terrific and Isabela Merced as Hawkgirl both make memorable impressions. Their inclusion expands the world without overwhelming the story, and both actors make the most of their screen time. Mr. Terrific finally gets the attention he deserves, while Hawkgirl adds a welcome layer of grit and power to the mix. Nathan Fillion as Guy Gardner / Green Lantern is one of the more divisive choices. While Fillion's comedic instincts are solid, the overall presentation-particularly the styling and tone-feels out of step with the youthful energy of this reboot. The film seems aware of this, even poking fun at it, but the joke doesn't quite land. Krypto, Superman's canine companion, adds a dose of wild, chaotic fun. His scenes are brief but effective, providing levity in a way that feels natural to Gunn's playful storytelling sensibilities. As for the film's surprise cameo, the mystery character who appears near the end feels oddly misplaced. Without revealing who it is, this interpretation leans too heavily into humor, undercutting the gravitas of the character's legacy. It's a creative risk that will likely polarize fans. John Cena's uncredited appearance as Peacemaker, on the other hand, is short, sharp, and perfectly executed. It's a quick gag that fits Gunn's trademark humor and doesn't distract from the main narrative. Superman (2025) may not be the strongest superhero film of the year, but it's a promising and spirited start to a new DC Universe. James Gunn delivers exactly what you'd expect from his direction-heart, humor, and a sense of community among heroes. While some tonal inconsistencies and casting choices prevent it from reaching greatness, the film succeeds in reintroducing Superman for a new generation. It's a light, entertaining, and optimistic theatrical experience-one that reaffirms the character's enduring appeal while paving the way for a brighter DC future. 6

review: A Shallow Reboot for the Man of Steel - Superboy in a Superman Costume? Honestly, I came into this movie with high hopes. A new take on Superman directed by James Gunn sounded like a promising start for the new DC universe. But after watching it, I left the theater feeling underwhelmed. To put it simply, the movie felt cheesy. The plot had no real depth. Gunn's Superman didn't feel like the iconic character we're used to. He felt more like a teenage, overly nice "Superboy" just trying to please everyone. He was saving people left and right, but not in a way that felt inspiring. More like he was desperate for approval. Compared to Henry Cavill's Superman, this version had no weight, no presence, no real character. Lex Luthor's hatred toward Superman also felt forced. There was no build-up, no emotional core behind it. Just pure villain mode with no explanation. And Lois Lane? The chemistry between her and Clark was almost non-existent. They kiss a couple of times and argue a bit, but nothing about their relationship felt convincing. At one point, Lois wants to break up with Clark, but that plot thread goes absolutely nowhere. Suddenly she's risking her life for him. It just didn't add up. Even the supporting cast didn't do much for me. Nathan Fillion is hilarious and usually a scene-stealer, but even his Guy Gardner couldn't save things. And Hawkgirl? That hawk scream was just unbearable. Loud, annoying, and way too frequent. It completely broke the immersion for me. I'll admit, the action scenes were well done. They looked great. But let's be real, it's 2025. That's the bare minimum for a superhero movie now. The post-credit scenes were completely forgettable. They felt like filler, not exciting setups for what's next. Overall, this Superman reboot felt like it was trying too hard to be light and hopeful, but ended up being shallow and unconvincing. It had the heart in the right place maybe, but no soul behind it. More like a flashy Bollywood-style take on Superman with none of the weight that makes the character timeless. Final verdict: Meh. Some cool fights, but no substance. 5

review: "Up Up and A failure" After years of anticipation, the 2025 iteration of Superman has finally landed, and unfortunately, it crashes and burns faster than a Kryptonian spaceship without its guidance system. Touted as a fresh take on the Man of Steel, this film instead delivers a muddled narrative, uninspired action, and a portrayal of its iconic hero that feels shockingly hollow. From the outset, the film struggles with its identity. Is it a gritty reboot? A lighthearted adventure? A character study? It tries to be all of these things and, in doing so, becomes none of them effectively. The pacing is erratic, lurching from slow, exposition-heavy scenes to rushed, incoherent action sequences that leave you more confused than thrilled. The biggest sin, however, lies in its depiction of Superman himself. The new actor, while physically imposing, delivers a performance that lacks the inherent warmth, hope, and moral fortitude that defines the character. This Superman feels distant, almost apathetic, and his struggles come across as whiny rather than genuinely conflicted. His interactions with Lois Lane, often the heart of Superman stories, are devoid of chemistry, reducing their legendary romance to a series of awkward exchanges. The villain, a generic, CGI-heavy threat whose motivations are as clear as a mud puddle, offers no real challenge or intrigue. Their grand plan is vaguely destructive, and their inevitable defeat feels less like a triumph for our hero and more like a foregone conclusion that simply takes too long to arrive. The special effects, surprisingly, are a mixed bag. While some shots of Metropolis are visually impressive, many of the action sequences suffer from an over-reliance on weightless CGI, making the destruction feel more like a video game cutscene than a cinematic event. Even the score, usually a soaring highlight in Superman films, is forgettable, failing to evoke any sense of grandeur or emotion. It's as if the filmmakers were so preoccupied with "deconstructing" the hero that they forgot to make a compelling movie. "Superman (2025)" is a missed opportunity of epic proportions. It takes one of the most beloved characters in fiction and strips him of his essence, leaving behind a bland, unengaging spectacle. Fans hoping for a return to form for the Last Son of Krypton will likely leave the cinema feeling more disappointed than inspired. Here's hoping the next attempt can actually fly. 164

review: Pretty Good Movie Rating - 7.7: Overall, a pretty good superhero movie that lays the foundation for James Gunn's DCU and David Corenswet's Superman; the former uses his traditional quirky and humorous interjection style, which he was known for with Guardians of the Galaxy, to make an entertaining movie, and the latter has the charisma and character to fill the suit; while I do commend them for taking such a big risk talking about real world issues in their biggest property, it does so in such an on-the-nose and shallow way that it makes the audience feel dumb. Direction - Good: The direction on a macro scale feels very James Gunn, as this movie feels very similar to Guardians of the Galaxy; The direction on a micro scale feels similar to Guardians of the Galaxy, but is still profound in getting the most out of the actors in the more dramatic moments; The storytelling is very similar to Guardians of the Galaxy, but is a little too simple and overt for the audience; They build tension in a way similar to other superhero movies Story - Pretty Good: The concept is Superman at his lowest as he is learning he is not as invincible as he thinks he is, which is a bold strategy to start your Superman on; I do admit it is very commendable for them to use their biggest property to tackle real-world issues, but it was a little too on-the-nose and shallow that it kind of just makes the audience feel dumb when they talk about these things; The plot structure is pretty linear and traditional to other Gunn movies; Character writing is surprisingly good as they build moral compasses for all these characters that superhero movies really shy away from, and this makes you actually care about them and want to see what happens next Screenplay - Pretty Good: The dialogue is very James Gunn, quirky and filled with humor, but it does have its profound moments; The humor is very traditional to James Gunn; The symbolism is honestly a little too on-the-nose and shallow, as it is not subtle at all what these conflicts are supposed to mirror in the real world, but them discussing morality and duty is pretty good; The foreshadowing is decent Acting - Pretty Good to Good: David Corenswet - Good (He has the charisma and character to fill the suit, as he really embodies the role; He has good chemistry with Brosnahan; Side note, this dude just seems like a really chill guy that I would want to hang out with), Rachel Brosnahan - Good (Plays Lois Lane very well as she is smart and independent, yet a strong love interest to Kent, led by the good chemistry she has with Corenswet), Nicholas Hoult - Pretty Good to Good (Plays Lex Luthor well, as casting someone who lost the part of Superman was a genius move; A little over the top, but it is pretty obvious this role is supposed to emulate Elon Musk and Jeff Bezos, even though that is just who Lex Luthor really is), Edi Gathegi - Pretty Good (Basically the typical comedic relief character you see in James Gunn movies), Anthony Carrigan - Pretty Good (Plays his role well), Nathan Fillion - Pretty Good to Good (A comedic relief character that is traditional to Gunn movies, but I enjoyed the banter he had with Superman throughout the movie), Isabela Merced - Pretty Good (Really was not used well, but I enjoyed her presence and wish to see more of her in future DCU movies), Rest of the cast - Pretty Good (Everyone feels like their role is carved out by Gunn because they all help tell this quirky, comedic superhero movie that the director is known for) Score - Good: Interpolates the original John Williams themes throughout the movie and modernizes them to create a modern Superman Soundtrack - Good: Feels very James Gunn curated, so good Cinematography - Bad: I honestly hated the cinematography for this movie because it was just way too close to the subjects and was nauseating at times; review: Not a masterpiece, but a damn entertaining Superman movie SPOILER Just got back from watching the new Superman - and honestly, I really enjoyed it. No, it's not some cinematic game-changer, but it's a big step in the right direction for the DC Universe. After years of messy CGI and tone-deaf storytelling, this one actually feels like it has some heart and vision. Let's start with the good: The action scenes are excellent. Heavy, grounded (as grounded as Superman can be), and visually really satisfying. The CGI? Surprisingly great - especially considering how rough DC's effects have been in recent years. And Krypto the Superdog? He absolutely steals the show. He's fun, never annoying, and actually plays a meaningful role in the story. Totally worked for me. David Corenswet as Superman really fits the role. He doesn't come off as some untouchable god - he feels human, hopeful, and just genuinely good. He wants to help everyone, sees the best in people, and carries this real sense of idealism that just feels like Superman. I thought he did a fantastic job embodying that. That said... the movie definitely has its issues. There's a lot going on. Honestly, too much. The plot jumps around like crazy, trying to juggle multiple storylines and characters, which means a lot of stuff ends up underdeveloped. Clark Kent barely exists in this movie - he's on screen maybe twice - and because of that, his relationship with Lois Lane lacks emotional depth. We're told they love each other, but we never really feel it. Also - and this bugged me - Superman gets his ass kicked way too often. I get it, he's still early in his career here, but damn, he gets ragdolled in pretty much every fight. He constantly needs help to win. After a while, it starts to chip away at the Superman mythos a bit. He doesn't feel powerful - he feels like the guy who might win... if backup arrives in time. Lex Luthor was another mixed bag. Nicholas Hoult is great in the role - cold, intelligent, menacing - but the script doesn't fully commit. At first, he's genuinely terrifying (there's a Russian roulette scene that's brutal), but then by the end, he's basically a punchline. Literally. Crypto chews on him like a toy while Superman chuckles. It undercuts the threat he was building up to be. One more thing: the comedy. Sometimes it works. But other times, especially during emotional scenes, it completely undercuts the moment. There's a big plot twist about Superman's parents and his true purpose on Earth - something that should shake him to his core - and instead of letting that emotion breathe, they throw in some jokes about his dog. It's not constant, but it's enough to notice. Despite all that, I really did like the movie. It's flawed, sure - too crowded, a little tonally uneven - but it's way better than most recent DC films, and it actually made me excited about where the new DCU might go. It's not going to be for everyone, but for me? It was fun, surprisingly heartfelt at times, and it left me wanting more. If you're open to a younger, more hopeful, sometimes vulnerable Superman, you'll probably have a good time too. 2

review: Truth, Justice and the James Gunn Way SPOILER So far this year, movies have either exceeded my expectations and impressed me, or fallen short and left me wanting more. I didn't expect Superman to fall into neither category. Instead, it landed in a third: exactly what I was looking for. When you go into a James Gunn movie, you're more likely to get a comedy with superheroes than a traditional superhero film-and this is absolutely a James Gunn movie before it's a Superman one. His signature humor is present in almost every scene. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't, but that's not necessarily a negative. Comedy is one of the hardest things to pull off. Despite the film occasionally feeling cluttered, nearly everything else pays off. If anything, it should've been longer-or even split into two films-because there's just so much going on. Lois Lane is great here. She finally feels like more than just a damsel or plot device. She rises above the 70s version in terms of agency while still feeling more authentically "Lois" than Amy Adams' portrayal. That said, the real standouts are Lex Luthor and the Justice Gang. All three members of the Justice Gang land perfectly. I was especially surprised by how much I liked Mr. Terrific. I sincerely hope he becomes a recurring character in the DCU. Edi Gathegi finally gets a role that doesn't waste his talent, unlike his previous superhero outing. Lex Luthor is perfectly petty. He's exactly what I want Reverse-Flash to be: a jealous, vindictive crybaby-and I mean that in the best way possible. I appreciated the film's effort to humanize Superman, though his tantrums sometimes bordered on unintentionally funny. Still, Krypto is a highlight, and the broader DC universe is set up really well. If this film proves anything, it's that DC is finally in the right hands. My main criticisms are a few questionable character choices. Why is Ultraman a clone instead of just using Cyborg Superman? Why does Otis feel so indistinguishable from Luthor's other goons? And why-somehow-does Skyler Gisondo as Jimmy Olsen work so well? Honestly, the Daily Planet scenes stole the movie. As I mentioned earlier, this is more of a James Gunn film than a traditional Superman film-but that's okay. I still had a great time and am genuinely hopeful for the future of the DCU. review: A Masterpiece of Directorial Self-Indulgence SPOILER 1:Exhibitionism of the camera In this film, James Gunn's obsession with close-ups reaches pathological levels. A shattered Lex Luthor wineglass? OK, let's give a close-up shot. A child waving a Superman flag? Interminable close-up. It seemed as if the director was constantly showing off to the audience: "Look at my composition!" If the director's noble intention was to make the audience constantly aware of their distance from the film, thereby giving them time to go back to real life and look around the awkward atmosphere, then he indeed achieved this. 2:The Physics of Boredom The battle scenes of Superman were supposed to show a powerful kinetic impact force. However, every scene shot by Gunn was inferior to the action scenes in "Mission: Impossible". The scene involving entering the pocket universe was simply like shooting a computer screen saver. I even wondered if he didn't hire a martial arts director at all. 3:Narrative Metastasis from GotG I admit that Gunn is good at shooting ensemble dramas, but he is a bit too stuck in his comfort zone, resulting in Superman being portrayed as Guardians of the Galaxy. Here, supporting characters swarm like narrative locusts, there are numerous pirated rocket raccoons and witty rogue heroes who advance the plot, while Clark Kent becomes a guest star in his own film. 4: Structural bankruptcy of editing The film's 130 minutes feel simultaneously rushed and interminable. Jump cuts during the climax of the film suggest an editor fighting to salvage foundationless stakes-a climax without crescendo. And the "comedic" (in fact, not at all funny) forced delay also seemed out of place. Apart from Kent and Luthor, the motives of the other characters are ambiguous, illogical and simply incomprehensible. I don't care whether Gunn's Superman has accurately recreated the image in the minds of comic fans or not. Gunn's fundamental failure is prioritizing directorial "voice" over cinematic discipline. review: Omg, that hurts This movie feels like a complete misfire. The tone is all over the place - one moment it seems like a cartoon for 6-year-olds, the next it throws in brutal violence. Lex Luthor screams like a maniac, Superman himself acts unstable and aggressive, and even his dog is portrayed as hyperactive and unhinged. Instead of mythic gravitas, we get over-the-top tantrums. Visually, it doesn't look like a $200 million blockbuster. Many scenes are shot way too close, giving the impression of a TV series or even a cheap TV movie. The so-called "battlefield" looks like a repurposed BMX track with a few extras running up the hill - sometimes even the exact same shot reused. It's hard not to feel insulted as a viewer. On top of that, it's an absolute catastrophe for anyone with basic geographical knowledge to hear such ridiculous fake country names like Boravia. It feels lazy, almost insulting. They could have done better research - or simply asked ChatGPT for help - instead of serving the audience this nonsense. What's worse, the attempt to inject "Guardians of the Galaxy"-style humor completely falls flat. That irreverent comedy works in space with a talking raccoon and a tree - but here it just undermines Superman's mythic tone. The result feels chaotic, soulless, and directionless. I honestly feel sorry for Henry Cavill and Dwayne Johnson - they dodged a bullet by not being part of this mess. And I truly feel bad for the cast here, because I'm convinced they could have delivered so much more if they hadn't been wasted on poor direction and incoherent storytelling. Compared to the heart, depth, and organic storytelling of the Arrowverse's Supergirl or even the classic Christopher Reeve films, this one is a disaster. 2

He gets beaten multiple times, only uses his heat vision once at the end, and demonstrates his ice breath just twice-one time to save a random dog on the street. On the positive side, I appreciated the portrayal of Lex Luthor. He comes across as intelligent and cunning, but I can't shake the thought that he allowed his girlfriend to record selfies and videos around his secret plans. Shouldn't a guy like him, who is supposed to be one of the smartest people in the world, be more careful? I also enjoyed his connection with Krypto, which led to some funny moments. The choice of Guy Gardner as a Green Lantern is intriguing (for those who read the comics, you know he's often seen as the biggest jerk among the Lanterns). If they had chosen Hal Jordan or another character, they might have provided more assistance. What really frustrates me is that he doesn't intervene while Metropolis is falling apart due to a massive crack in the earth, but he does go to stop the war.
